Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Module-Centric Approach to Integrated Adaptation of Assembly Products and Supply Chains

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop new modeling methodologies for concurrent product assembly module design and supplier selection. Such methodologies will support quick and efficient adaptation of product assembly modules for high product variety, and allow identification of key interrelation between product module re-configurations and supply chain performance. The approach of this research is to develop three methods and integrate them: (1) graph theory based assembly representation method incorporating product and supply-chain information, (2) subassembly generation method by hierarchical multi-layer assembly decomposition, and (3) mathematical models for linking subassembly modules with suppliers for supply chain efficiency using multi-objective computation methods. Case studies will be conducted jointly by participating universities and industry partners in order to validate the above methods. Deliverables of this research include mathematical models, heuristics algorithms, software and materials for education and technology transfer.

The success of this research project will transform assembly decomposition and supply chain design from disjointed processes into an integrated decision-making process, providing a more holistic view of the manufacturing enterprise and its all value stream partners. The graph-theoretic assembly representation and decomposition methods will provide innovative ways to model and plan assembly products more effectively, and will increase the level of concurrent engineering. These enhanced modeling capabilities and decision making tools will help minimize unnecessary lengthy iterations between the design department and suppliers, and improve U.S. manufacturing competitiveness by helping bring products to the market rapidly at reduced cost. The developed methodologies and models can lead to software systems and information technology infrastructure useful to industry. The education program will promote learning, teaching and transfer of new technologies to industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manufacturing system design is consisted of a set of complicated activities.  Two important activities are manufacturing process planning and supply chain design with the manufacturers and many suppliers involved. While manufacturing process planning is associated with decisions such as the sequence to assemble components into products and how to define subassemblies considering various manufacturing constraints, supply chain design is concerned with assignment of the subassembly work to the participants in the manufacturing network. These two activities are actually interwoven with each other due to the fact that the definition of subassemblies also impact the supplier assignment and vice versa. This interrelationship between the two sub-activities makes the product development time-consuming and costly as industrial practitioners must consider issues from both when making decisions. The research supported by this award aims at integrating and synchronizing the two activities so that concurrent and optimal decisions can be made in manufacturing system development.    

The project began with a comprehensive review of the literature on assembly and supply chain representations, followed by identification of the research gaps on integrated representations. To fill the gaps, a new graph based representation was developed to integrate assembly and supply chain configuration information and decisions. After formulizing the integrated design of assembly and supply chain as an optimization problem with the objective to minimize the total cost, we developed an algorithm to search for an assembly and supply chain configuration at the lowest cost among all the feasible configurations. A second algorithm was also developed considering lead time constraints. The method was tested on randomly generated products for computational performance and applied to a laptop assembly case study under different supply chain conditions. The results showed that our method can obtain optimal solutions in a computationally efficient manner and provided decision makers insights into assembly planning and supply chain designs.

As manufacturing is now powered by the internet and big data analytics, the outcomes of our research will enable manufacturers to integrate the resources across the supply chain so that the manufacturing capabilities could be fully utilized and ultimately that the products could be delivered to customers in a shorter time and at a lower cost. An example of application of the method can be seen in automobile industry, in which modular assembly and supply chain is becoming the new trend as suppliers are making efforts to focus on their core value adding activities. This modular trend has shown its potential to reduce product development cost and lead time. Our method can help suppliers determine modules and assign the modules to their lower tier suppliers. The outcomes of this research will help the manufacturing industry advance toward responsive and resource efficient manufacturing.
